title: Wisdom for Kings and Life
shortSummary: Proverbs 25 contains wise sayings of Solomon, compiled during King Hezekiah’s reign, offering practical guidance on leadership, relationships, and self-control. The chapter emphasizes the value of humility, patience, and righteous conduct, revealing how godly wisdom benefits both rulers and individuals in everyday life.
timeline: c. 715-686 BC - Reign of Hezekiah, King of Judah, during which these proverbs were compiled

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: The wise king of Israel who authored the proverbs, known for his God-given wisdom.

keyCharacters.name: Hezekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who commissioned the men to copy and preserve Solomon’s proverbs.

definitions.definition: Impurities or worthless matter removed from metals like silver during refining.
A ruler or person of high rank, often a king or noble in biblical context.
A metaphor for causing conviction or shame, leading to repentance or change.
Speaking maliciously or slanderously about someone behind their back.

outline.heading: Introduction and the Majesty of God and Kings
outline.description: This section introduces the source of these proverbs and contrasts God's hidden wisdom with the king's duty to seek understanding, highlighting the inscrutable nature of divine and royal hearts.

outline.heading: Guidance for Kings and Proper Conduct Before Authority
outline.description: These verses teach the importance of removing wickedness from leadership and counsel, and the wisdom of humility rather than self-promotion before rulers.

outline.heading: Practical Wisdom for Relationships and Speech
outline.description: This section advises carefulness in disputes, the value of timely and wise words, the importance of faithful messengers, and the power of patience and gentle speech.

outline.heading: Warnings Against Excess and Unwise Behavior
outline.description: The final section warns against overindulgence, meddling in others’ affairs, false testimony, misplaced trust, and lack of self-control, emphasizing the need for self-discipline and peaceable living.

application: Approach conflicts with patience and seek resolution directly with those involved to maintain integrity and peace.
Practice humility before authority and avoid self-promotion, trusting God to elevate you in due time.
Control your speech carefully, offering timely and wise words that build up rather than tear down.
Exercise self-control in all areas of life, recognizing that lack of discipline leaves one vulnerable and exposed.

keyVerses.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the honour of kings is to search out a matter.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the divine wisdom in mystery and the noble responsibility of leaders to seek understanding.

keyVerses.text: Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men: For better it is that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.
keyVerses.significance: These verses teach humility and the wisdom of waiting for God’s timing rather than self-exalting.

keyVerses.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in pictures of silver.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the beauty and value of timely, appropriate speech in building relationships.

keyVerses.text: He that hath no rule over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down, and without walls.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the critical importance of self-control as a defense against moral and spiritual ruin.
